data.text: Iâ€™ve seen a few questions on here about the Vango F10 Project Hydrogen, or similar lightweight bikepacking solo tents. Iâ€™ve been using mine for a little over a year and thought Iâ€™d share my thoughts. A little over 700g, packs down to the size of a water bottle, double-walled, surprisingly good living space and weather protection, no tent poles just an air beam. This means itâ€™s really compressible and easy to mount into bike bags. Overall, Iâ€™d say Iâ€™ve been very impressed but definitely strong pros and cons. Was a little dubious of the airbeam but as long as itâ€™s pumped enough it holds strong. The massive PROS are the weight, size and living space. Itâ€™s lighter than a lot of bivvy/tarp combos and more practical than things like Tarptents which might require a tent pole. For me, the CONS are the lightweight materials (Iâ€™ve not had issues but itâ€™s SO thin you have you to be careful) and also the pitching takes a bit of getting used to. Itâ€™s also expensive, at about Â£500. For short-haul bikepacking/touring trips through 3 seasons, I think itâ€™s a pretty nice option. If it was a little cheaper, Iâ€™d say itâ€™s a VERY nice option! Happy to share any more feedback and Iâ€™ve also put together a video with my experience and tips for use, if you want any extra info: [https://youtu.be/XtgR5vTLHGI](https://youtu.be/XtgR5vTLHGI) Happy rides all :)
Looks amazing. Thanks for your review.
data.author: Adam Doane

data.text: no problem ðŸ™‚
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Used the Helium for over a decade and it has been everywhere, which has proven to be an amazing tent. I replaced it with the Hydrogen and it feels pretty much the same material-wise and is so far living up to the same standards, just a lot smaller and lighter. My only annoyance was the Airbeam. Initially, I was using a small Lezyne nano pump and after 45mins of pumping, it got nowhere! Did consider using CO2 inflaters but the waste involved, and the bulk of a cylinder each day, along with the possibility of the cold freezing the beam and destroying it was too great a worry to consider. I tried a track pump at home and that inflated the tent in no time, but that wasn't exactly packable. I've now changed over to a Frumpa Minipump (electric mini pump) and I'm getting over a week of tent inflations out of a charge on it and it has the tent up in 45secs now...far handier when you need shelter in a hurry trying to avoid bad weather.
data.author: Allan Rutland

data.text: a few people have mentioned this. Inflating by mouth and then finishing with the pump takes a little over a minute. Doing the whole thing with a hand pump is a grueller ðŸ˜… glad to here the longevity hasn't been an issue. That's something I've been concern2d about but have only used for a year.
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Its definitely a good tent, but very pricey! A good alternative if you're in the USA and don't mind a short pole is the REI Flash Air 1. Right around the same weight (730g) and will pack the size of a waterbottle without the pole. The only drawback is its probably not going to work if you're over 6'3.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: Six Moon Designs Haven or Lunar duo is a fantastic option as well.
data.author: Keri-Tracy Sprenger

data.text: wish REI produexts were available in the UK. Such good value!!!

data.text: Wish we could get UK products here in the EU without being kicked in the sack with import charges and fees....actually I might favor getting kicked in the sack if they didn't exist.....

data.text: I have the flash air 2 and it's a nice tent and it's super light. It's non freestanding so you need to plan out where you pitch.
